The march of the Irishry and their notable brags being far from their enemies, wherein they discover openly their courageous dastardly hearts.With three and three in ranks beset,
to do some enterprise.
They make a goodly show,
’till near they come at hand:
They set themselves most lively forth,
like conquerors of the land.
But when they are in reach,
or compass of the bow:
The stately courage of the Rebels, is soon put down, at sight of our Prince’s host.does not the view of Prince’s host,
Kern’s courage overthrow?
Their pride is what God must assuage,
where fear does pluck it down:
Fear a suppressor of the sturdiest Rebel’s heart.What Rebel would not stand aghast,
to meet the royal crown.

The order of the Irish war is plainly set out, who leaving the order of battle array, being near the combat, fall into a cluster, therein they suppose their safety to consist, making a most terrible noise of crying to terrify (if it were possible) the whole host of English men.Now warlike array they leave,
and on a heap they clung:
Supposing safer for to be,
as better foes fight.
And with a mighty cry,
our host they do invade:
But son repulsed back again,
by warriors piercing blade.
The Trumpets sound me forth,
the skirmish to reveal:
And murdering guns their secret grudge
no further may conceal.
Here bullets fly abroad,
there darts again are sent:
And blow for blow in recompense,
to either part is lent.
The horsemen scours the coast:
with shaking spears in hand:
Boasting Woodkern do first give back.And Rebels which before did boast,
now ’gin to fly the land.
Still sound the trumpets forth,
each Soldiers’ heart to cheer:
And captains with two-edged swords,
do give the traitors gear.
Here lies a Rebel’s head,
Under these covert titles, the valor of all our English Captains are expressed.from shoulders taken quite:
And here the Lion’s tearing paws
on woodkern’s head light.
The Gryphon here assays,
to have his manhood known:
Whose valor hath sufficiently.
from time to time been shown.
The Eagle with the rest,
no lesser honor hath:
When as his bill and talents both,
O Soldiers of renown shield you from mischance, which do in spite of Irish kern, your Countries praise advance.in Rebels blood he hath.
And all the lusty youths,
belonging to the train:
To purchase fame by Marshall acts,
their azure veins do strain.
Woodkern must needs sweat, for their labor is great.Now go the foes to wrack,
the Kern apace do sweat:
* The piper seeing the Kern to have the worst end of the staff, do lull the Irish retreat.And bagpipe then instead of Trumpets,
do lull the back retreat.
Who hears the Bagpipe now,
the pastime is so hot:
Commendations worthy of right, to belong to our English Captains, who never shrinketh, but with great valor and manhood tarrieth the final end of the battle.Our valiant Captains will not cease,
’till that the field be got.
But still they forward pierce,
upon the glibbed route:
And with their weapons meet for war,
these boasting foes they clout.
Lo yet behold a Knight,
our Prince’s proved friend:
In armor ready for to fight,
the quarel so to end.
No danger ought to be eschewed, nor labor refused, in the defending our prince and Country’s cause.This seeks by warlike means,
his credit to augment:
And for his Prince and country’s sake,
his Pistol forth is sent.
Which does relate the cause,
of her exceeding Ire.
The jealousy of a Prince devoureth like the flames of fire.As how her just conceived wrath,
surpass the flames of fire.
That may not be extinct,
(signs verify the same:)
The anger of a prince ceaseth not ’till he hath brought his purpose to perfection.’Till cutting sword and piercing spear,
Rebelling foes do tame.
Here lies a breachless Knave,
smote just from coursers back:
Thus through the soldiers’ brave hearts,
the Woodkern go to wreck:
The Irish Kern’s hearts now more and more do faint.Now faint the ugly beasts,
for Lyon plagues them so:
As they are like to Bedlam folk,
that knew not what to do.
* Irish Woodkern had rather fly then fight, and good reason they have so to do, for who would take blows if he can shun them.To fly they dare assay,
for so they think it best:
As for to stand to fight it out,
their souls do it detest.
Their hearts are mollified,
with fear they are oppressed:
Mark Traitors in the midst of battle is no place to repent.And now they wail ye thing which wrought
them this unquiet rest.
* A notable question that demands, if the repentance of a vile catrife, and rebellious Woodkern, may satisfy the Injuries committed against our Queen.But will repentance serve?
I put herein a case:
Or may it satisfy the wrong,
done to her (noble grace?)
When Lion once is stirred,
he by and by does rage:
And t’will be long who knows it not,
before his anger assuage.
A similitude of the Lion.And when he once begins,
to show his Princely force:
He stints not ’till he turneth his foes,
into a breathless corpse.
The Prince’s pleasure put in execution by Sir Henry Sidney.Even so the Irish Kern,
which do our Queen provoke:
do throughly feel by Sidney’s hand,
the weight of Lion’s stroke.
For why? he binds them down,
he strikes them in the chase:
Rigour is meetest where clemency availeth not.When gentleness prevaileth not,
then rigor taketh place.
And rigor being shown,
the terror of the same:
That which is done by compulsion, is no god-a-mercy.Perforce does make them celebrate,
her thrice (renowned name.)
But then it is too late,
Justice and fortitude yields Rebels their hire.for Justice commeth in:
With Fortitude that (worthy person,)
to contribute their sin.
The Soldiers wreck their anger and displeasure upon the poor Irish kern without all pity.They prosecute the chase,
pursuing fast the foe:
And with their weapons framed to war,
O hard hearted men that takes pity of none.the Kern they overthrow.
Here lieth a pack of Kern,
distract of limb and life:
Woodkern abides the brunt of fortune.Here headless Knaves abide the brunt,
of warriors mortal knife.
The Kern receive the foil,
being overcome by might:
Irish Kern fight with their heels with greater courage, then with their hands.And for the saving of their lives,
each one does take his flight.
The piper and his bagpipe laid both flat on the ground.The Bagpipe cease to play,
the Piper lies on ground:
And here a sort of glibbed thieves,
devoid of life are found.
* The Woodkern’s legs must help them when hands will not serve them.Now fly whose luck is best,
the luckless man let stay:
And now bewail thou Irish Kern,
thy hapless hap I say.
Very good counsel given to the remnant of Woodkern, warning them how they do attempt anything prejudicial to the honor of the Crown.Lament thy woeful state,
deplore thy fatal chance:
And warful be against (our Queen,)
how ye your selves advance.
Yeah good advisement take,
before you do provoke;
As the Lion is feared, and reverenced of all the beasts in the Forest, so ought a King to be feared and loved of his subjects within his Realm.The Lyon for no mortal person,
his purpose may revoke.
For as he is the Prince,
and king of every beast:
So would he have obedience shown,
from most unto the least.
The reward of Rebellion is death.Else if you should fight,
against his noble mind:
You might expect at hands of his,
nought else but death to find.
A caveat for Woodkern.Let this a lesson be,
to this Rebelling route:
To Macke, and O. to Rorie Ogge,
to all the Traitors stout.
Good reason that the Asses calamity should make the Fox to beware.Let Brian’s fall suffice,
let Wolf and Fox beware:
How with the noble Lyon they,
the gotten pray do share.
Still sound the trumpets forth,
the foe to terrify:
And Soldiers with courageous hearts,
The cord that rebellion did bind, may not be loosened by any means, but by the engine of death.upon the Kern do fly.
The Kern apace do fall,
like leaves through blustering wind:
And may nowhit release the cord,
that they themselves did bind.
* The Irish Kern’s cry.Bohbowe now cry the knaves,
and lullalowe the Kern:
And English youths a warning send,
rebelling foes to warn.
The remnant of the unslain Woodkern, do part take the Bogs, and other some the Wood.Here part do take the Bogs,
and some the woods retain:
And other being headless made,
like witless Geese remain.
Irish colts are tamed by the snaffle of war.Thus boasting foes are tamed,
by crowds of warlike youths:
Receiving strokes instead of rewards,
for their inconstant truths.
English men return Conquerors.The victors do return,
they have their hearts delight:
For Woodkern they are knocked down,
the rest are put to flight.
Untrust remaineth not one,
which may the least annoy:
For winds are stilled by mighty Jove,
O cause of endless joy.
Sir Henry Sidney is worthily renowned for prudence and magnanimity.Sir Henry is renowned,
with fame unto the Sky:
And is receiv’ed to Dublin town,
prais’ed for his chivalry.
Peace commeth of war.Thus peace ensues by war,
the end of war is peace.
A Godly prayer that Ireland ought to use.God grant the wars of Irish son,
by Sidney’s means may cease.
Lo Lordings here the draught,
of that which went before:
And land descried, the wished tide,
hath brought my Ship to shore.

hi.seg:
Fter that I had finished the first and second part of the Image of Ireland, and had there somewhat disclosed the nature and quality of the wanton Irish wild Woodkern, I thought it expedient for the volumes augmentation, as more ampler by examples to prove the things therein contained, to put next in sequence, the picters and protractors of the most notablest Rebels in Ireland, (who as they are many) so do they ask sundry operations, if of each several one I should make relation. (And again) musing in my mind with whom I might encounter, as best begin withal, having sundry choice to chose upon, I supposed it a thing necessary, and at this instant fittest to serve my turn, to lay the foundation of my attempt, & sure substantial corner stone, upon Rorie Ogge our next neighbor, at this present (a lively Image & pattern of rebellion) who after many pageants of treasons played, and notable offers of grace refused, being brought into great misery (by Sir Henry Sidney the Lord Deputy’s daily instigation) and seeing him self utterly forsaken both of God
H.i. and
and man, at last moved through a desperate and condemned conscience, confessing his folly, manifesteth to the whole world, his crooked nature, complaineth of his fatal destiny (and finally) as it were through a certain conjecture, foretelleth of things that shortly shall happen him. Wherefore behold in plain protractor, a gross and corpulent man, lapped in a mantle overwhelmed with misery, being in a Wood (an ill favored Churl) standing on a Hillock enclosed with a shaking Bog (his only refuge in the time of trouble) uttering most lamentably, with brinish salt wolfish tears, his life as ensueth.

lg.l: Rorie Ogg showeth here the County wherein he dwelleth, and his natural inclination, whereunto he is addicted.I Rorie Ogge, inhabitant of Leasse,
A rebel false, against my (sovereign queen)
I love debate, expelling godly peace,
I lead my life, in Bogs and thickets green,
What mortal person, my compare then hath seen,
Which of ye Lord nor prince does stand in awe,
Nor pass not for, the rigor of the Law.
Mark where unto this Rebel’s heart is bent, (that is to say) to all kind of mischief, sin and wickedness.My heart is bent, to every kind of ill,
Whose outward deeds, do well relate the same
I love the thing, supporter of my will,
I spoil and burn, thereby t’increase my fame,
Thus by such acts, I gotten have a name.
Even traitor false, that never shall decay,
Nor be extinct, by any kind of way.
I vilain vile, and crafty as the Fox,

** Rorie in accusing himself, is not to be judged of other, for here he showeth that he is as crafty as a Fox, an extortioner like the Wolf, falser then a thief, and a traitor to the Queen, in which I believe him, though he never swore for the matter. Yeah like the Wolf, which does extortion use,
I falser am, then thief that picks the locks,
In devilish sort, myself I so abuse:
(My noble Queen) for chief I do refuse,
Whose royal name, does mount unto the sky,
And the game to the hounds where, is in authority.

Rorie Ogge going forward in the setting out of his disposition telleth that he does all this kind of mischief of set purpose against ye queen, who notwithstanding, layeth al the blame and fault upon the Devil.What may displease, her princely royal grace,
(I like a thief) do put the same in vre,
Her highness’ Laws, I daily do deface,
And through ye same, her heavy wrath procure:
Thus Satan he, my senses does allure,
Who makes them thrall, to serve his appetite,
So that in nought, but sin I do delight.
She would me good, if I would loyal be,
But my ill hap, and cruel Destiny,
In part or whole, that thing forbideth me,
’Till Eyes constrained, through Sidney’s policy:
Her mighty hand, perforce to testify,
Prostrating me, before her fearful Law,
Though of the same, I stood not erst in awe.

** In this he manifesteth the great goodness of the Queen, whose mercy is daily extended towards those which are willing to yield to the observation of her statutes and laws, but he in no wise may yield thereto, ’till by compulsion he be constrained. And forced perforce, God knows what does remain
But cruel plagues, for my recompense are just,
Such is the rewward, which every Rebel gain,
That does pursue, the chase of raging lust:
O careless Kern, O Rebel false to trust,
** Rorie Ogg being compelled to acknowledge ye great authority of the Prince, is therfore worthy of small god-a-mercy. O Rorie Ogge, thrice cursed may I be,
Who mov’ed to wrath, the queen’s high majesty
Wo ** Where Rorie bid the three curses light upon him, I wish him for every one twenty (saving my charity.)may I be, for moving her to Ire,
The M. woes, through which my soul possess
In each respect, surpass the flames of fire,
I languish still, but hopeless of redress:
My wicked life, I needs must now confess,
Through which I feel, even live ye pangs of hell,

* A good note for Rebels, Marks the effect, of rebellion, and whereunto it driveth this wretched Roge, even to the brink of desperation, who as he sayeth being yet alive, feeleth most apparently the torments of hell, and here it is proved true, that a man’s own conscience is better then a thousand witnesses.That neither pen, nor tongue of man can tell.

There be two sorts of people on earth, knaves and honest men, whereon I gather that Rorie Ogge being banished the company of honest men, must be entertained of his like equal companions, (who as him self sayeth) is daily pursued of the good in most woeful sort.I am expelled, from crew of honest men,
None but my mates, me traitor may abide,
As for the good, they hunt me now and then,
From woods to Bogs, beset on every side:
And where that I, so ever am espied,
There weight is laid, to catch my silly soul,
And with the axe, to short me by the pole.
Which thing to taste, I well deserved have,
** Rorie is here a very penitent person, which confesseth his life to have deserved death, which refused the prince’s pardon once offered him. Since freedom once, was offered unto me,
Vain is the gift, that’s proffered to a knave,
Who nought esteems, his Prince’s elemencey:
O Rebel cause, of all thy misery,
Which mightest have had, remission of thy sin,
What, greater gain, supposedest thou to win.
O hapless person, refusing Prince’s grace,
** Here Rorie Ogge taketh on with himself for refusing the pardon, & acknowledgeth himself an ass, and a beast in denying the same. O dismal day, wherein I it denied,
O perverse heart, that couldst not it embrace,
But like a thief, such courtesy denied:
O brutish beast, who does not now deride,
The boasting heart, aspiring over high,
Whose haughty thoughts, did match ye rouling sky.
But true it is, that Fatal letters say,

Rorie calleth to memory the saying that is written, time being once past, is not easily called back, whereby we are learned to take the time present whilst it is offered.Who takes no time, when as the same is lent,
And hold it fast, himself thereby to stay,
Whom if it pass, the crooked way it went:
He may not find, the Tavern, House or tent,
Though them to seek, he spendeth day & night
And all because, he held not when he might.

He verifieth and approveth the above saying by himself, which rejecting grace being offered, now seeketh after it, but may not have it, though with weeping he does request it.Even so alas, when noble Sidney he,
My pardon sent, for faults I did commit,
Though there I saw, each crime forgiven to be,
I not content, with chat his pardon yet:
Let pass the same, as gift for me unfit,
Which to revert, now lies not in my might,
For God & time, have wrought me this despite
* Rorie Ogge showeth for pardon, but may not obtain it, for Prince’s by Rebels will not be deluded.Now do I seek, though seeking nought prevail
Fain would I find, the favor of my Prince,
But craft serves not, that stately fort to scale,
For well she knows, my subtle hearts pretence
Who hath a time, the same to recompense,
As seemeth good, unto her royal grace.

* Rorie Ogg seeing himself environed on every side with enemies, manifesteth his misery, showing not one crafty house or den to be free from the knowledge of ye Lord deputy, but that he hath intelligence and knowledge of it.For God and time, bid Justice to take place.
And Justice she, sends forth her warlike crew,
With sundry spies, my haunt for to disclose,
Who cunningly poor Rorie’s tract do view,
Relating it unto his mortal foes:
As nought is left, wherein he may repose,
’Mongest all his dens a bulwark for his health
Nor yet a hole, to shroud his gotten stealth.
* Rorie showeth how spiteful greedy, the English Captains and Soldiers are in chasing and hunting him.Like greedy hawks, pursuing fast their prey,
All fully bent, the same for to devour,
And as the Night, the Oriental day,
does captive make, by his external power:
So time from time, small distance from an hour,
Persuade I am and brought to such a bay,
As I expect, nought but my dismal day.
Rorie acknowledgeth ye Lord Deputy’s notable wisdom, only to have brought him to this misery.Sir Henry now, who governs Irish soil,
Hath made an oath, to ’breviate my days,
Whose stratagems, have given me such a foil
As all the land, sounds out his noble praise:
For he it is, that breaketh down my stays,
And who but he might Rorie overthrow,
Though Mars himself, had sworn my mortal foe.
He proveth his affirmation by a most manifest example, which was brought at that time to pass.Who might have taken, out of my bloody hand,
Whom by my deceit, I captive made to be,
That Marshal knight, and captain of a band,
No second one, (except again t’were he:
In fine ’twas he, which made of bondmen free,
Rorie Oge’s wife is slain.And put to sword, for my unstable truth,
My spoused wife, the garland of my youth.

* Rorie’s friends to the number of sixteen are slain in a cabin, being in a Wood of the English men, and afterward the cabin being set on fire, all their bodies are burned also.With many more, my dear and special friends,
Whose breathless corps, were given to flames of fire
Good cause had I, to wail their luckless ends,
Though Jove agreed, to yield them such a hire:
O heavy plague, to move the heavens to Ire,
Through whose outrage, ye just oft suffers pain
To cause the rest, from wicked acts refrain.
And I myself, in danger of my life,

* Rorie Ogg being at that time in the foresaid cabin, with those that were killed hardly escapeth, though not without a good knock of a halberd upon his head.Round encompassed then, by men of worthy fame,
Sought out to shift, how to escape the knife:
That ready was, my courage for to tame,
Which when that I, well pondered had the same
I took good heart, it stood me then upon,
And leapt me forth, time wild I should be gone.
To leap well is very necessary sometime, as appeareth here by Rorie Ogge.Now with that leap, I got me quite away
most joyous that, I escaped the trap,
My legs were good, to vow that thing I may
Which set me free, that tide from that mishap
Not over free, for one gave me a rap,
Which thing I swear, did pinch me to ye hart,
The blow was great, & came so overthwart.

Rorie here showeth that the English men, were very sorry for his escape out of the cabin, and from their hands. This happiness is to be referred to the English men, whose chance was to kill those rebellious knaves. Rorie Ogge especially does bewail the death of one Shane Macke Rorie Reagh above ye rest that were slain at ye time.But ’scape I did, so much the more their grief,
And got me soon, into an other den,
None fled with me, but one poor only thief,
As for the rest, they were saluted then,
That instant time, were xvi of my men,
Put to the sword, in tents where we lay,
O my ill hap, but happy theirs I say.
Amongst them all, one ancient aged sire,
Whose counsels I, each while did well allow,
Though old he was, yet piercing as the fire,
A crafty Fox, as any liveth now:
Was murdered then, by chance I know not how
Whose cruel fall, given by the sisters three,
Alas, alas, full sore disquiets me.
Here he setteth out ye cause why he so deploreth his destiny.For whilste he liv’ed, my heart possessed his lust,
And lust enjoyed, what so it could invent:
But since the post, whereon my hope did trust,
Receiv’ed his dome, by warriors fierce assent,
Like thraldom’s slave, I sithens have been pent.
Rorie Ogge being be robbed of his counselors, is all most out of his wits.In easeless hold, not witting what to do,
Or what were best, to put myself unto.
When Rebels lack supporters and helpers, then fall they to misery.My men were slain, which only were my stay,
My wife through whom, I often gat relief,
My friends which brought, to Rorie day by day
The stolen horse, the Mutton and the Beef,
Which things to want, who holds it not a grief?
Yeah such a plague, as authors tell to me,
That to a man, no greater plague can be.
The first step to Rorie’s misery.Lo first the woe, my soul does over quell,
Behold ye straight, whereto I now am brought,
Mark well the place, where caitiff I do dwell,
As eke the knight, this alteration wrought,
Then shall you see, if thoroughly you have sought
The perfect way, that leadeth to the hall:
Where are the plagues, on Rorie Ogge shall fall.
The Lord Deputy is in armour against Rorie Ogge, whose fame is spread universally through out the Realm of Ireland.For Sidney now, that thrice (renowned knight,)
T’augment the fame, and service of his (queen)
Stands out in field, by sword to try her right:
(Whose valiant heart, like to the Laurel green,
For courage stout, and prudence mixed between,
Is had in Price) renowned for the same,
Through Irish soil, with trumpets of happy fame
Sir Henry Sidney encreaseth Rorie Oge’s misery, and worketh his subversion by his notable industry.He sundry ways, does aggravate my smart,
He he I say, hath wrought me sore annoy,
His wisdom’s skill, hath daunted sore my heart:
And my attempts, does utterly, destroy,
He day from day, his actions does employ,
False Rorie’s days, to ’breviate with speed:
Because that he, so vile a life do lead.

Soldiers are sent out to put in practice, the Lord Deputy’s purpose.
Rorie playeth the Astronomer this star was sene from Dublin south west, by which blazing star, Rorie Oge conjectures his speedy fall, which accordingly happened. By these once and for all, are meant Mores and Comores Rorie’s chief friends.His Marshall knights, & expert men of war,
By him are sent, to put the same in vre,
Who me of all, my freedom do debar:
Whereby I may, not long their force endure,
But force no force, since I did so procure.
Both heaven and earth, to be my mortal foe:
If in their rage, they Rorie overthrow.
Behold a Star, apparent in the West,
** This H. does signify, how Macke Shane which is Rorie Oge’s father in law. Whose fiery streams, I find by learned skill,
Betokeneth peace, tranquility, and rest,
When M Ms & Cs, to serve false Rorie’s will,
Debarred shall be, for thereof come the ill.
Or if that H. had serv’ed his Queen a right,
Long sithens R. had been rooted up quite.

*This is a true and good confession of Rorie Oge, uttered in his extremity. Rorie Oge is in his similitudes up to the hard ears, proving with manifest arguments, unless he had been bolstered up by his said father in law and his friends, it had been impossible that he should have continued so long unexecuted or taken. When H. does well, to deal with double hand
Else from his kind, he should degenerate.
But if that S. his deceit did understand,
H. should be turned, augmenter of debate,
In little space, unto a viler state,
* Though yet not spied, he goeth uncorrected:
Which is the botch, wherewith R. is infected.
* Like as that house, whereon him self to stay,
Hath sundry posts, by workmen fastened sure,
With every puff, may not be blown away:
So long as they, in linked state endure,
Even so myself, I do you all assure,
Shall scarce betrapt with Fortune’s fatal chance
Whilst friends with aid, my mischief do advance.
But posts remov’ed, the house son hath a fall,
Mark here Rorie’s reason, which speaketh by experience.And building goeth, with violence to wrack,
No part may stand, the roof nor yet the wall:
When as the same, his understays does lack,
Even so myself, nowhit could hold out my grasp.
Except that I had underpropped been:
By him or them, that seem friends to the queen.
God’s blessing hast thou good Rorie for speaking the truth.Which if they were, from Rorie once remov’ed,
Who would misdoubt, ye peace that should ensue
This by his like, the wise hath often prov’ed:
As now by me, it may be held true,
Rorie Ogge taketh upon him here, to have skill in Physic.If that the cause, whereon the Phistoll grew,
Had first been taken, from patient clean away:
No Phistoll then had sprouted there I say.

As the Lord Deputy abridged the days of some of Rorie Oge’s fosterers in this his visitation, so he prophesied of the end of the rest of his said friends together with himself.But as a part, is protected through fatal chance,
Or by the deceit, of Sidney’s prudent skill,
So in good time, the rest shall trace that dance:
Which hitherto, have serv’ed my wicked will,
And since that they, have nursed me in mine ill.
They shall receive, with me for their reward:
A reward due, long since of Jove prepared.

* Rorie sees by some secret way that his prophesy is at hand, ready to be performed, and so much the more he is certain of it, because he does see Sir Henry Sidney bent wholly to his destruction.That time draws nigh, and hour is at hand,
In which the clan, of my rebelling race,
Shall be extirpated, and abolished clean the land:
(For God himself, do sit in judgement place)
To Judge I say, with Justice now the case.
Which time from time, hath ever been deferred:
So that the right, at no time could be heard.
Rorie Ogge taketh this scythe to be the sword of Justice, which the Lord Deputy hath plucked out of the sheath only to do execution upon all transgressors.Lo lo I see, in Mower’s cruel hand,
A fearful Scythe, which does prognosticate,
Both here & there, throughout this Irish land
That growth of things, are at their ripened state
Which must be cropped, by Scythe of dismal fate.
For God and time, hath sworn by sacred other:
That Reed & husk, shall suffer penance both.
It is at hand, for fields declare the same,
The date is out, and time appointed spent,
And reapman now, the boaster to reclaim:
The Harold of death is sent to Rorie Oge, certainly to make manifest, his ruin and fall.In Ireful rage, from mighty Jove is sent,
Whose message thus, unto me does present.
Affirming R. to come to desolation:
And his supporters, to suffer like destruction.
Then men shall walk, upon the mountains high,
The peace is described that shall be after the death of Rorie Oge.And fear nowhit, the Tiger, Wolf, nor Bear
The Kids shall sleep, with Leopard quietly:
And yet nowhit, his fearful visage fear,
For why? no cause, of trembling shall be there.
When as the thing, whereof they were afraid:
Shall be by sword, and cruel conquest laid.

The Lord Deputy in prosecuting his purpose against Rorie Oge, & through procurement of the said Rorie’s fall, deserveth everlasting remembrance, with all good & famous men.Then H. & S. through whom this peace does spring,
For his recompense, shall crowned sit with Fame,
And over that, which is a better thing:
He shall possess, an everlasting name,
Amongst the just, that well deserve the same.
And though ye time, shall turn his corpse to clay
Yet shall his name, still flourish as the Bay.

Rorie Oge maketh here his conclusion, and giveth forth a good exhortation to all men, counselling them to eschew and flee treasons, and showeth though sins be for a while let go unpunished, yet at length they are recompensed at full.Lo you that live, and I that soon shall dye,
Behold I say, the salary for sin,
Now let my cause, teach other imps to fly:
From treasons lure, lest stipend like they win,
For though ’tis long, ere Justice cometh in.
Yet when it comes, it payeth once for all:
And suffereth plagues, by heaps on plagues to fall.

hi.seg:
Ntering into the discourse of Rorie Ogge, at the first, I was purposely bent, friendly with him to adjoin the lives of many (the open professed enemies of her Majesty’s government within this Realm of Ireland) but before I had ended that portion (even in the midst thereof) I beheld many impediments, wonderful obstacleless, stops, and stays persuading the contrary, which being replenished with sufficient matter, ground upon reason, wisdom advised me, to consider thereof (least peradventure) ranging on rashly, I might seem to prosecute an endless work, making a volume, more greater, then grateful, and more painful, then pleasant, (which thing doubtless) I utterly abhor. Seeing that praise consists not, in the quantity, but rather, in the quality & grace of a thing done. And thus I ’breviated my former intent, though in effect, nothing diminishing that which I promised. For in this discourse, you may
perfectly
of Ireland.
perfectly se, as in a glass, perceive, learn, and understand, to what vexations of mind, troubles of body, anguish and wretchedness in conscience all the rabble of Rebels are captive unto. Wherefore leaving them with their ungracious Patrons; Physiognomies, external; and infernal, to thy consideration (gentle Reader:) It came then into my mind, freshly to gather my wits together, to the setting forth of an other manner of thing, of greater valor then as yet thou hast seen (that is to say) the coming in of O’Neill to (Sir Henry Sidney our Lord Deputy of Ireland) at the Newry, with his submission, the other that the said O’Neill then and there made, touching his perpetual fidelity, and inviolable continuance of his dutiful allegiance, to the (queen’s Majesty her royal Crown and dignity) with sundry other promises more, decently becoming every good Subject: not barely in words to say, but actually in deeds to accomplish and perform, which if I had passed over in silence, some perhaps would have blamed me of partialities, who in this Image so sharply inveighing, against the wickedness & rudeness of woodkern,
should
The Image
should have omitted such a president of humble submission, wherefore behold the said O’Neill here making his submission, as before is said, whom the Lord Deputy in the (Queen’s Majesty’s) behalf most nobly accepteth, rendering such honor as to his person appertaineth. The effect whereof hereafter followeth.

lg.l: If beasts which have no understanding, do rejoice at winter’s departing, and at the coming in of summer, (the increaser of their delights) much more ought that man, who being long without the prince’s favor, and kept in disgrace, be triple joyous, (received at length to mercy and favor)IF silly beasts, long pent in drooping stale,
Or if the Heart, sore pinched with chilling cold,
No marvel joys, to see the Summer fall,
Through which the plants, kept down in massy hold
Their fragrant scents, & beauties may unfold.
Or if the Lark, when clouds are passed away,
Te deum sings, to see the Sunny day.
Why should not man, the highest firmament,
Whose thoughts did pierce, where Jove resplendent sit
Whose outward shape, the same does represent:
As next extend, for his forecasting wit,
To whom alone, he only does commit.
The vestal world, with ruledome of the same:
The fish in Seas, and beasts on land to tame.
Rejoice I say, unbound from thousand cares,
From grief of mind, with sorrows overpressed,
From sighing sobs, far fetched with trilling tears
From heaps of cares, clos’ed up in panting breast,
From everything, that might gainsay his rest.
And now in place, and stead of such annoy:
To reap at full, his long expected joy.
This joy at full, I mean my Prince’s grace,
The favor of the prince is an inestimable treasure to that subject which hath it, surmounting pearls and precious stones.The chiefest wealth, that subjects can require,
A learned judge, to soil each doubtful case:
As readiest way whereby men may aspire,
To honor’s seat, from youth which all desire.
A peerless pearl, esteemed more worth then gold:
And more of price, then Diamonds to be sold.
A tower of strength, and fort of Fortitude,
This setteth out most lively in sundry, forms and fashions, what a thing the favor and grace of our Queen is.A Samson strong to rive the gates asunder,
A mighty Sea, that land from land exclude:
A brave Mars, which Nations bringeth under,
A second Jove, that worketh much wonder.
A passing star, to guide man’s Ship a right:
A pleasant field, and garden of delight.
O who can tell, expressing every part,
The happy estate and condition of good subjects, is without all comparisons.The exceeding joy, that loyal Subjects win,
Or who can show, the thrice redounding smart:
That reachless lives, to rebels bringeth in,
Which make things seem, as though they’d never bin,
(O pearl of price) to honor Prince’s Laws:
Of health and wealth, the sole and only cause.
Indeed, I think if there were any grace at all in him, which is once brought to be a subject, he may not lightly be turned to be a Rebel again.Who so did taste, once of that Sugared life,
And reap the fruit, that springeth of the same,
Be it wildest Kern, b’it infant child or wife:
Wert fearest foe, by conquest worthy fame,
wert-Macke, or O. Macke devil wert by name
I think if grace, did them conduct a right.
Theilde no exchange, though change at will they might
If hap to change,* Truly the condition of Rebels in Ireland is very ticklish, and their chances very hard, as in this part is described. the change for worser part,
As trial tells, each where in Irish soil,
In reachless change, things light overthwart:
For though the foe, in treasons field do drudge,
Yet dreads he sore, each while to get the foil.
And though for once, he passeth by the trap:
Yet at the length, in pantle he shall hap.
A most plain and true description of Rebels’ timorousness.Yeah though their straights, hard fortune to expel
Are hundred Kern’s prepared at all assays,
Yet every Rush, their haughty hearts does quell:
As witchly wind, their courage sore allays,
Thus fear them daunt, by 1000 kind of ways.
They fear to see, the shiv’ring of the day:
They fear as fast, when it is passed away.
Fear every while and where, troubleth the Rebel, waking, sleeping, and at all times and seasons.Thus fear each while, environeth traitor’s mind,
And cares again, to shield them from mischance,
They are disturbed, at every puff of wind:
The dusked clouds, which over them do glance,
They say foreshowed, some sudden fatal chance.
And often times, the shadow of a tree:
Makes them believe, a band of men to see.
The traitor that thinketh himself in most security, is often times brought into greatest perplexity, such an horrible thing is treason.Such fear turmoils, the sturdiest of them all,
Such fear I say, each Rebel does retain,
Such fear I vow, upon the best does fall:
Such fear I swear, the chiefest foe does pain,
Such fear again, in loftest heart remain.
And though such fear, does overwhelm their hearts,
Yet cease they not, to play disloyal parts.
Rebellion is a very foolish play and pastime, and most foolish is he, that filleth his heart and stomach with treason as if it were with most wholesome meatSuch play may well, be counted fools game,
For none but fools, therein do take delight,
Just was the cause, whereof it held the name:
As eke a curse, that brought it first to light,
Instead of food, to glut man’s appetite.
And band are all, in City, Field or Town:
That hold such play, against the royal crown.
Those that live well, and love well their Prince, is everywhere counted happy & blessed.But blessed are they, that do refuse the same,
And triple blessed, that love their Prince aright,
Blessed shall he be, which pretermits that game:
Yeah blessed I say, both morning and at night,
Blessed shall he be, which hath his whole delight.
In good attempts, and furthering Princ’s cause:
Conducting him, by tenor of her Laws.
This is the protestation of O’Neill to the Lord Deputy.My Prince’s friend, I vow myself to be,
And loyal eke, unto her noble grace,
A friend to her, a friend likewise to me:
As time shall try, the utmost of her case,
And who that seeks, her honor to deface.
I do protest, by all my force and might:
My blood to gage, but I’ll maintain her right.
This is largely proffered of him.In Prince’s cause, my hand shall strike ye stroke,
And who that dare, her Scepter to defame,
As he that will, not yet again revoke:
By Marshall acts, that person I’ll reclaim,
And make him yield, submission to her name.
Yeah though he were, a second Mars I vow:
I’ll make him stoop, to break, to bend, or bow.
Few Scots in North (if Queen will have it so)
O’Neill promiseth to expel all Scots out of the North of Ireland, if the Queen’s Majesty would but give him aid, or if her grace would have it so.Shall there abide, the ground for to manure,
Except that they, their homage yield her to:
Avowing eke, their fealty to endure,
Conjoining it, with compliments most sure.
Not one I say (if Queen will me support)
Shall there possess, one castle town or fort.
Since I have reaped, the thing I did desire,
And won at last, the favor of the crown,
My heart is set, as ’twere in flames of fire:
Meaning Sir Henry Sidney, to whom O’Neill made like protestation.By service just, t’augment her great renown,
Which shall appear, by Rebels plucking down.
Withstanding them, that shall withstand her right:
In midst of field, (I vow’ed it to her knight.)
An admonition to the inhabitants and borderers near to the NorthLet them beware, that border near my hold,
In any case, how they their lives do lead,
For with an oath, to vow I may be bold:
If to their cuts, they take not better heed,
In heart and mind, I fully am agreed.

O’Neill promiseth not only to be a scourged to the evil livers and disturbers of her Majesty’s people, but also a friend and helper of her good subjects to the uttermost of his power.The best to quell, (that shall molest her grace:)
Dismissing them, from honor, life, and place.
But *those that lead, a faithful subjects life,
I their defence, do put myself to be,
Supporting them, in every kind of strife:
Defending them, from cruel tyranny,
By way I say, of noble chivalry.
And whereas I, may do them any good:
For Prince’s sake, I’ll hazard life and blood.
Come each spirit, which now do haunt the wood,
Submit your selves, unto your sovereign’s law,
Come forth I say, receive my counsel good:
Let not fond lust, your senses thence withdraw,
But of the crown, like subjects stand in awe.
So shall you find, such favor of the Queen:
As hitherto, the like you have not scene.
Instead of woods, then houses you may use,
Instead of Bogs, the Cities at your will,
Proceed therefore, lest time you should abuse:
Now reap the fruit, of pleasure even your fill.
Let loyal love, Rebelling fancies kill.
(In fine) submit, you (to her royal grace:
So mercy shall, arrest you with her Mace.

hi.seg: HE miserable calamity ofRorie Oge set out by means of the deadly pursuit of valiant servitors daily pursuing him, remained nothing to the concluding of my labors, but the final ending of his wretched race, which thing I constantly believed would shortly come to pass, (admirable both to the beholders and seers) for as his life was notorious and passing knavish, so could it not otherwise be, but that his death must agree, falling out equal in each condition to his traitorous usage, for seldom is it seen, that wicked rebelling hath a blessed ending, and as men oftentimes hope not in vain, so I expecting, or rather wishing, the cutting of (of such an infected member (received at length, the reward of my expectation, in the fullness of the thing I so long thirsted for. (For as God would) it came luckily to pass, (long time predestinated by his unsearchable and secret counsel) soon after, as I had ended with the description of O’Neill, that this cursed caitiff, (cursed of gods own mouth)

was through the sword, by the means of the Lord of Vppossery and his servitors (a faithful subject of that Realm) bereaved of his life, to the great tranquility of Lease, and elsewhere (her Majesty’s league people there inhabiting) according to the true prophesy, in his living story, at large set out. Wherefore, and for as much, as I suppose your desire is, to hear some discourse concerning his death, as you heard before touching his life, suppose that you see a monstrous Devil, a trunkless head, and a headless body living, the one hid in some miskin & dunghill, but the other exalted, yeah mounted upon a poll (a proper sight in which God to behold (boasting itself on the highest top of the Castle of Dublin, uttering in plain Irish the things that ensue.

lg.l: In this part Rorie Oge showeth the state of that man to be sure, so long as he keepeth himself dutiful to his Prince and Country.WHilst fear joined with hope, liege people retain,
A fear to offend, the Prince or her law,
And hope for recompense, such goodness to gain:
As shall be imposed, to the line they draw,
Whilst one uprightly, twixt these stands in awe.
He dreads no turbulent storms that may chance
For time trieth falsehood, the truth to advance.
But fear expulsed, clean out of the mind,
That man which casteth of fear falleth into many mischiefs.Not weighing Justice, detector of sin:
And hope of correction, which subjects does bind,
Their lives for to lead, the statutes within,
Are lightly extend, when rancour begin,
To play her pageant, as wily she can:
She spoileth wholly, the nature of man.
He that hath wicked rancour in his breast, hath with it also a great number of evil vices. Time is a detector of treason.Procuring envy, grudge, strife, and debate,
Anger, and malice, both fit for the turn,
Dissimulation, a principal mate:
That other vices, does neatly adorn,
Holding them smouldering, and never to burn,
’Till time descries it, detecting the treason:
Which then is maintained, by color of reason.
Alleging reason,Treason espied, is excused by reason. such folly to cover,
Though treason not reason, is chiefest pretence,
Thus whilst in malice, the Rebel does hover:
Raising a power, to be his defence,
To subjects disquiet, the Realm and the Prince,
Good God what reason, is it then to defend,
The thing that treason, is found in the end?
That traitor which is willfully given to play the Rebel, hath never regard to the cause be it good or bad, for which he riseth.But man addicted, to fancy and will,
Forced by Sathan, to follow his lust,
Regards not the cause, be it good or ill:
For which in hazard, his life he does thrust,
He pass not a might, b’it just, or unjust:
For as the Pooke leads him, so forward he must:
Not ceasing ’till bayard, layeth him in the dust.
A Rebel does not remember what is the end of his treasons.He nought forecasteth, inflamed with ire,
At last what guerdon, false treason award,
Nor yet discerneth, through passing desire:
What plagues for traitors, ye law hath prepared,
But running forward, not having regard,
To things before him, or after ensue:
He son possess, what for treason is do.
Though fortune does favor the traitor for a while, yet at last she leaveth him in the briers.Although for a time, dame fortune does smile,
favoring most friendly, the thing set abroach,
Whose crafty suggestions, compact in a wise,
At last brings the Rebel, to shame and reproach,
Deluding his rashness, that dared to encroach,
So much on fortune, abusing her wheel:
That least puff of wind, does make for to reel.
What here is spoken, a thousand have tried,
Who may be trial, the truth will declare,
Many have found fortune very deceitful.The course of fortune, they likewise have spied,
As how she seeketh, but people to snare:
To snarl and entangle, with sorrow and care,
And they thus hampered, from them to fly,
Suffering those captives, in fetters to lie.

To augment the misery of man, fortune does some time seem friendly, ridding him out of one small trouble, to bring him in to four greater, and then bids him ado.Yet she forsakes not, still men in their need,
But sometime favoreth, their hardless distress,
As who that listeth, in stories to read,
Shall see how friendly, she seeks their release,
Though for no true love, yet more to increase,
The plague of vengeance, that after ensue,
(A stipend justly, to traitors b’ing do)
These things to confirm, I Rorie am he,
* Rorie Oge is a sufficient witness, to tell of Dame Fortune’s variableness.Who sometime mounted, a loft in the Sky,
And fortune casting, a favor to me:
Provoked me higher, and higher to fly,
Thus like an Eagle, I nestled on high,
Full little thinking, again to descend:
Or that my glory, would ever have end.
Mark how fortune did favor Rorie Oge, according to his own setting, who being to much besotted therewith, fell to utter confusion and shame at last.In all my actions, most happy success,
Dame Fortune, ever allotted to me,
For what I minded, in heart to suppress:
The same accomplished, she caused to be,
Thus will and fortune, did ever agree,
Which thing espied, puffed up with aspirance:
I stood with Sir Henry, alas at defiance.
Much like a champion, addicted to war,
Rorie Oge gathereth eight score men to maintain his knavery.Time serving fitly, to anger my foes,
I summoned a number, of neighbors from far:
Twice eighty persons, the best I could chose,
For manhood, and deceits, in whom to repose,
I might in safety, my life and my land:
No dastards nor shrinklings, but those it would stand.
Rorie Oge troubleth both Town and Country with his Kern, and setteth more then a hundred houses on fire in one night.With these I marched, from place unto place,
With these I troubled both Village and Town,
With these in one night, I fired the Nace:
With these my Recisters, I spoiled of renown,
With these I made many a Castle come down,
With these I yielded, augmenting my fame:
The people to sword, and houses to flame.
With these I wasted, the County of Lease,
The places likewise, that bordered it nye,
Rorie Oge maketh the Farmers of Lease to give over their plowing, by reason of his daily robbing and burning.I made from tillage, the Farmers to cease:
I made them gladly, away for to fly,
Inviting them nightly, with a fresh supply,
Giving my woodkern, their states to maintain
The fruit that growed, of other men’s pain.
But God detesting, this horrible life,
The just Justice of God permitteth not Rorie Oge to rage still on in his fury, but calling him to accompt yieldeth him his duty.Might not of Justice, permit me further,
To rage in such fury, delighting in strife:
Contemning virtue, addicted to murder,
His Justice, and Judgment, meeting together,
For my demeanor, since willful I climbed:
Awarded me death, long sithence deserved.
And here I lie growling, poor wretch on ye ground
Rorie Oge head is set upon the top of the Castle of Dublin, for a spectacle to all the whole land.Spoiled of the Jewel, I chiefly loved,
Thus God of Justice, does traitors confound:
When from their sins, they’ll not be removed,
With shame and confusion, I now am reproved,
My head from the body, parted in twain:
Is set on the Castle, a sign to remain.

Rorie Oge maketh here his conclusion and giveth wholesome counsel more better than he ever could take, how they attempt anything that might be prejudicial to the prince, for fear of like destruction.All men that hear this, take warning by me,
Least that ye fall, in like predicament,
The art of treason, see likewise ye flee:
Wisely forecasting, whereto ye consent,
Against the Crown royal, do nothing attempt,
For if against it, ye falling at odd:
Do feel as I felt, the strength of the rod.
